summ: The patient underwent a right modified radical mastectomy for a right breast cancer, with a clinical history of a right breast cancer and a concern for a deep margin positive result. The microscopic examination revealed a tumor consisting of tubules and cribriform glands composed of atypical cells with a moderate amount of eosinophilic cytoplasm and oval nuclei with distinct relatively small nucleoli. The tumor was diagnosed as infiltrating ductal carcinoma, measuring 2.5 cm, with a histologic grade of II/III and nuclear grade moderately differentiated. A non-comedo intraductal carcinoma component was identified, comprising less than 10% of the carcinoma. The deep surgical margin was negative for tumor. Vascular invasion was not identified, but two of seventeen lymph nodes were positive for metastatic adenocarcinoma. Additional findings included breast tissue with apocrine metaplasia and microcalcifications in non-neoplastic lobules.

summ: The patient underwent a right hemiglossectomy with neck dissection for a T3 squamous cell carcinoma of the oral cavity. The tumor was moderately differentiated, keratinizing, and involved the intrinsic tongue muscles. Vascular and perineural invasion was present. The anterior, posterior, and deep tongue margins were free of carcinoma, but the carcinoma extended to the anterior and posterior floor of the mouth margins. The pathologic stage was pT3 N2b. The re-resection of the anterior and posterior floor of the mouth margins showed no tumor. The biopsy of the medial posterior floor of the mouth/tongue showed invasive squamous cell carcinoma based on the original frozen section slides. The neck dissection, levels 1 through 4, showed metastatic squamous cell carcinoma in five of 24 lymph nodes, involving levels 1A and 2, with extranodal extension and vascular invasion present. Microscopic examination substantiated the diagnosis of invasive squamous cell carcinoma.

summ: The patient underwent a total thyroidectomy with the final diagnosis of multifocal, bilateral papillary thyroid carcinoma. The carcinoma was identified in at least 7 foci, ranging from less than 0.1 to 1.5 cm in size, with the largest focus being 1.5 cm in the right mid lobe. The carcinoma showed conventional type with focal tall cell features, angiolymphatic invasion, microscopic extrathyroidal extension, and carcinoma extending to the surgical margin. Molecular testing revealed a BRAF mutation, but no mutations in NRAS61, HRAS61, KRAS12/13, or RET/PTC1 and RET/PTC3 rearrangements. One lymph node was examined, and no tumor was present. Additionally, an oncocytic follicular (Hürthle cell) adenoma was identified in the right lobe, and chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis and nodular hyperplasia were also present.

summ: The patient underwent a left neck dissection, composite resection, and additional tissue removal. The microscopic description revealed invasive, well-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the left composite resection, measuring 5.5 cm, with tumor invasion up to the mandibular bone. The margins were negative for tumor. Osteonecrosis was also noted. The lymph nodes from the left neck dissection levels 1, 2, and 3 were negative for tumor. The proximal and distal mandible, anterior floor of the mouth, left retromolar trigone, posterior floor of the mouth, left anterior buccal mucosa, left buccal mucosa posterior, left gingival buccal solstice, left lingual alveolar ridge, tongue, and pterygoid were all negative for malignancy. The additional left mandibular bone and tissue showed bone with osteonecrosis, but no evidence of malignancy. Tooth #23 was gross only, with no malignancy seen.

summ: The patient underwent a brain tumor excision biopsy with multiple specimens submitted for pathological examination. The results of the microscopic description are as follows: The meningeal tumor (specimens A and B) is a fibrous meningioma (WHO Grade I) with extensive necrosis, previously embolized, and a MIB-1 proliferation index of 2%. The tumor cells are positive for EMA and show a mitotic index of about one per ten high power fields. The intra-axial tumor (specimens C, D, and E) is a glioblastoma (WHO Grade IV) with a high MIB-1 proliferation index of 30-35%. The tumor cells are densely infiltrating cerebral cortex and adjacent white matter, with prominent nuclear anaplasia, frequent mitotic activity, microvascular cellular proliferation, and zones of necrosis. The tumor cells are positive for GFAP, synaptophysin, and neurofilament, and strongly overexpress the p53 protein. The MGMT promoter is methylated, indicating a potential benefit from therapy with alkylating agents. Allelic loss on chromosome arm 19q is detected, which is a typical finding in oligodendrogliomas with 1p and 19q deletion.
